annotation.TEXT: Well, there we have it. Though we're not quite done just yet, the credits sequence still gives me enough time to give my thoughts on this game. Overall, while there's quite a bit to slog through in the earlier sections, there's still some fun to be had with the later levels. There's no real question that Tiers 4 and 5 contain the really good stuff. Fortunately, you're not forced to play through the other Tiers first.
If you don't feel like sitting through all of these though (I wouldn't blame you for it, since it takes a while), feel free to skip ahead to 12:39 for the teleporter leading to Wily.

Aside from comparing him to the Wily fight, I'm not sure how else to describe Bright Man's battle. He just kinda throws out whatever random attacks he can come up with, not to mention that he has a lot of different moves at his disposal. It makes predicting and reacting to him a bit tough, especially if he gets in a habit of spamming some of his nastier attacks.

Admittedly, I forgot what the weakness to the third phase was for a moment. Without using weaknesses though, this fight can either be really easy or really annoying (it mostly depends on what random attacks he decides to use).

His second phase is a little more predictable, seeing as a lot of his attacks are now throwbacks to Square Root of Negative One's weapons. It's a nice touch, to be sure. With that being said, I don't particularly like the Flame Shield attack. Trying to jump over it just doesn't seem possible at times (though I suppose you could try to bait it into the air and then slide under it, but it moves pretty fast either way).

Yeah...This is one of those moments. I have almost nothing to add onto this joke, save for one interesting bit of information: As far as I can tell, this is the only boss in the game that takes static damage. As in, every single attack will only do 1 point of damage against him.

As implied, the arena is basically one big boss rush, done up in a style seen in some Kirby games. However, I can't help but think this also drew some inspiration from Rockman 4MI in some ways (aside from having a similar reference with its boss rush mode, both of them have secret optional bosses as well). For the sake of convenience, I'll be skipping ahead to said secret boss.

For what it's worth though, it's definitely an interesting experiment as far as contests go. If there ends up being a MAGMML 2, I'd definitely be interested to see how it plays out. I'm not sure if I'd submit an actual level for it, but I'd still play the end result either way.

Once again, I have no idea what any of this means (though if I had to take a guess, it's probably a reference to Kirby again). Much like Wily and Bright Man however, this thing specializes in the art of "throwing random stuff at you." Maybe the point of this fight was to be chaotic, but by this point, I'm getting kind of sick of it. I'm also not fond of bosses that spawn enemies (I'm looking at you, Rom), mostly because they tend to be more distracting than anything.
Feels like it's been a while since I've had the chance to use the Captain Planet joke. In any case... *ahem* "By their powers combined, they create..."
So then, remember back in Square Root of Negative One, when I said that sometimes these games speak for themselves?

With that being said, this game still has its fair share of issues. While I'm not as picky about the engine not being 100% accurate, the various glitches are definitely problematic; From the the finickiness of Rush Jet, to the top platforms not working correctly, there's quite a few bugs that should have been ironed out. Beyond that, some of the stages have their own problems here and there, as pointed out over the course of the playthrough.

Under any other circumstance, this room would be my personal hell. Fortunately, these aren't all boss battles, but rather mini-stages based on each of the contest entries. Granted, it still takes a while to go through each and every one of them. Given the choice between these or actual boss re-fights, though? I'll take actual stages any day of the week.

...The saddest looking Wily Machine I've ever seen; Not in terms of design, at least (I'm pretty sure it's supposed to be modeled after a trophy, hence the "1" on the side). It's mostly due the facial expression. It actually looks depressed (either that, or very disappointed).
As mentioned before however, we're not actually done yet. We still have a secret boss and the arena to deal with, both of which are found relatively close to each-other.
